docTitle.titlePart:
Laboratory diagnosis of the antiphospholipid syndrome: a
plethora of obstacles to overcome

front.div:
The antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune
disease characterised by recurrent vascular thrombosis
and ⁄ or pregnancy morbidity, associated with the pres-
ence in plasma of antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL).
APS requires the combination of at least one clinical and
one laboratory criterion (1).
Initially believed to be directed against phospholipids,
aPL are directed to plasma proteins with affinity for
anionic phospholipids. Antibodies against only two
plasma proteins, b2-glycoprotein I (b 2 GPI) and pro-
thrombin are found frequently enough in APS patient
plasma to attribute them a pathophysiological role,
today (2–4). Yet, correct diagnosis of this syndrome is
complicated by ongoing dilemmas on clinical features as
well as on laboratory methodologies applied (5–7).
As the incidence of clinical symptoms is high and
because these are often determined by underlying factors,
the diagnosis of APS relies predominantly on laboratory
results. The detection of aPL in the blood of patients
with a history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications
is an essential step, not only in the diagnosis but also in
the management of the APS (8). The laboratory diagno-
sis assigns patients with a common event (thrombosis) to
a group with a high risk for recurrence, which is a prere-
quisite for long-term oral anticoagulant therapy. Patients
with thrombosis and aPL may be given indefinite oral
anticoagulant treatment (9). Falsely diagnosed patients
may thus be exposed to a high risk of bleeding, without
having any benefit of such treatment.
An adequate laboratory detection of APS is therefore
clinically relevant. It is based on phospholipid-dependent
coagulation tests, which detect aPL as inhibitors of coag-
ulation, i.e. as lupus anticoagulants (LAC), and ⁄ or relies
on demonstration of the presence of anti-cardiolipin
(aCL) antibodies via an immunosorbent method (10, 11).
